questions.stem: What was the primary purpose of the Stamp Act of 1765?
choices: To restrict colonial trade with France.
To raise revenue from the colonies for Britain.
To pay for the housing of British soldiers.
To establish a colonial postal service.
questions.answer: To raise revenue from the colonies for Britain.
questions.rationale: The Stamp Act imposed direct taxes on paper goods in the colonies to help Britain cover debt from the French and Indian War.

questions.stem: The Boston Tea Party was a protest against which British policy?
choices: The Townshend Acts
The Intolerable Acts
The Tea Act
The Quartering Act
questions.rationale: Colonists destroyed British tea to protest the Tea Act, which gave the British East India Company a monopoly on tea sales.

questions.stem: Read the excerpt from a 1765 colonial newspaper. According to the writer, why do the colonists oppose the new taxes?
choices: They believe the taxes will stop westward expansion.
They want equal representation in Parliament before taxes are imposed.
They fear the taxes will lead to war with France.
They worry the taxes will end trade with the Caribbean.
questions.answer: They want equal representation in Parliament before taxes are imposed.
questions.rationale: The excerpt stresses that colonists should not be taxed without representatives in Parliament, echoing the slogan 'no taxation without representation.'

stimulus.text: "We cannot surrender our rights as Englishmen. If we are to pay duties, then we must have a voice in the body that levies them. Without representation, taxation is tyranny."

questions.stem: Which colonial organization formed to help coordinate communication and resistance to British policies after the Stamp Act crisis?
choices: Albany Congress
Committees of Correspondence
First Continental Congress
Sons of Liberty
questions.rationale: Committees of Correspondence allowed colonists to share information and strategies for resisting British policies.

questions.stem: Which event came first, helping to spark further conflict between colonists and British soldiers?
choices: Battles of Lexington and Concord
Boston Massacre
Declaration of Independence
Second Continental Congress
questions.rationale: The Boston Massacre occurred in 1770 and inflamed tensions years before open warfare at Lexington and Concord in 1775.

questions.stem: Study the table. What conclusion can be drawn about British taxation of the colonies after 1763?
choices: Britain reduced taxes because colonial trade declined.
Britain increased taxes to cover costs from recent wars.
Colonists paid fewer taxes once the war with France ended.
Parliament eliminated all duties on imported goods.
questions.answer: Britain increased taxes to cover costs from recent wars.
questions.rationale: The rising tax revenue after 1763 shows Britain demanded more money from the colonies to pay war debts.

stimulus.text: British Revenue from Colonial Taxes (in thousands of pounds): 1762 - 45; 1764 - 82; 1766 - 95; 1768 - 110; 1770 - 118

questions.imageSuggestion: simple line graph showing rising British tax revenue from 1762 to 1770

questions.stem: What action did the British government take in response to the Boston Tea Party?
choices: Passed the Intolerable Acts to punish Boston
Removed all taxes on colonial goods
Granted Massachusetts greater self-rule
Issued the Olive Branch Petition
questions.answer: Passed the Intolerable Acts to punish Boston
questions.rationale: Britain retaliated by enacting the Intolerable Acts, which closed Boston Harbor and limited self-government.

questions.stem: What was the British policy of salutary neglect?
choices: Strict enforcement of trade laws on colonial merchants
Limited interference in colonial affairs as long as trade benefited Britain
A military alliance between Britain and colonial militias
A law that required colonists to house British troops
questions.answer: Limited interference in colonial affairs as long as trade benefited Britain
questions.rationale: Salutary neglect described Britain’s relaxed enforcement of trade laws when the colonies remained economically profitable.

questions.stem: The map shows the Appalachian Mountains marked as a boundary line after the French and Indian War. What was the British goal in setting this boundary?
choices: To encourage settlement west of the line
To protect Native American lands and limit colonial expansion
To divide the colonies into northern and southern regions
To create new colonies for loyalists
questions.answer: To protect Native American lands and limit colonial expansion
questions.rationale: The Proclamation of 1763 barred colonists from settling west of the Appalachians to avoid conflicts with Native Americans.

stimulus.text: Map description: A line along the Appalachian Mountains labeled 'Proclamation Line of 1763' separating colonial settlements to the east from reserved western territories.

questions.imageSuggestion: map of eastern North America in 1763 showing the Proclamation Line along the Appalachians

questions.stem: How did the First Continental Congress respond to the Intolerable Acts in 1774?
choices: It declared independence immediately.
It voted to boycott British goods and petition the king.
It sent troops to attack British forts.
It accepted the Acts to restore peace.
questions.answer: It voted to boycott British goods and petition the king.
questions.rationale: Delegates agreed to halt trade with Britain and petition for the repeal of the Intolerable Acts while still seeking reconciliation.

questions.stem: Read the excerpt from Thomas Paine's pamphlet Common Sense. What does Paine argue the colonies should do?
choices: Accept British rule and avoid further conflict.
Seek representation in Parliament while remaining colonies.
Establish an independent nation separate from Britain.
Return control of colonial affairs to royal governors.
questions.answer: Establish an independent nation separate from Britain.
questions.rationale: Paine's pamphlet urged colonists to declare independence and reject monarchy.

stimulus.text: "Tis time to part. The blood of the slain, the weeping voice of nature, cries, 'Tis time to part.' "

questions.stem: Which British policy forbade colonists from settling west of the Appalachian Mountains immediately after the French and Indian War?
choices: Sugar Act
Proclamation of 1763
Declaratory Act
Quebec Act
questions.rationale: The Proclamation of 1763 set the Appalachian Mountains as the western boundary for colonial settlement.
